text: Well, I know French, Dutch, German, Modern Greek and Japanese. All of those come with quite a few complications though (French counts by twenties when above 60. Dutch and German put the units before the tens when spelled out, and write those as a single word, and in Modern Greek many numbers have different forms depending on the gender of the noun they complete. And I'm not even talking about Japanese, which has two different number systems to account for and many variations in number forms). Naively, this could be solved by massive lists of already spelled out numbers, but I'm not sure it's the right way to go...

text: Mmm... I think the spell-it approach, of a language-agnostic kernel wherein you can plug a language module with not only lists of strings but also language-specific processing functions might be the right way to go. But that'd require quite a bit of extra work as you want to support much larger numbers than what spell-it does, and you'll need a big refactor of what you already have to support such an architecture. And enough knowledge of the languages of the world to know what can be put in the language-agnostic kernel.
